raw_text:
Turkey deal 'to help world peace'
 
 A deal bringing Turkey a step closer to EU membership is of "fundamental importance" to the peace and security of the world, Tony Blair has said.
 
 The deal, struck at the European Council last week, also proved claims of a clash between Muslims and Christians were "wrong", Mr Blair said. It represented the achievement of an "historic British objective", he added. Tory leader Michael Howard said the deal laid to rest any suggestion the EU was "anti-Islamic".
 
 Turkey's involvement with the EU would provide an "invaluable bridge" between Europe and the rest of the world, Mr Howard added. But the Tory leader argued that the EU constitution was not designed to take in a country as large as Turkey. Mr Blair has been a leading advocate of Turkish membership despite controversy surrounding the idea. He insisted that the Turkish leadership had made great advances in improving its human rights records. The deal to open formal talks with Ankara came despite an EU demand for Turkey to recognise Cyprus.
 
 It was agreed the issue can be tackled at a later date but Turkish premier Recep Erdogan had to accept negotiations did not guarantee his country full EU membership. The internationally recognised southern part of Cyprus is an EU member, but Turkey, which occupies northern Cyprus, had previously insisted it would not bow to demands to recognise the country, calling the issue a "red line". It could take up to 15 years before Turkey is able to join, and entry cannot be guaranteed. If it joins, Turkey may have to accept restrictions to limit migration by its citizens. The EU has also announced that it will start accession talks with Croatia in April 2005. However, talks will begin only if the country co-operates fully with the UN war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
llama3.2:1b: A deal bringing Turkey closer to EU membership is seen as a key step towards world peace. The deal was agreed at last week's European Council and aims to address claims of Muslim-Christian clashes. Despite controversy, Turkish leader Recep Erdogan accepted negotiations, with the UK's Tony Blair saying it represents an "historic British objective".
llama3.2:3b: A deal bringing Turkey closer to EU membership is "fundamental importance" to world peace and security, according to Tony Blair. The deal, agreed upon last week, proves claims of a Muslim-Christian clash are "wrong" and paves the way for Turkey's involvement with Europe. The Tory leader Michael Howard says the deal will prove the EU is not "anti-Islamic". Turkish premier Recep Erdogan accepted negotiations without guaranteeing full membership, which could take up to 15 years and require restrictions on migration by Turkish citizens.
gemma2:2b: A deal granting Turkey closer EU membership is seen as a positive step towards world peace and was described as an achievement of a historic British objective. The deal settles the misconception of a clash between Muslims and Christians, providing an invaluable bridge between Europe and the rest of the world. Despite some resistance regarding the EU constitution's suitability for Turkey's size, Turkey's progress in improving its human rights record is being lauded. While formal talks with Ankara opened, full membership remains uncertain, requiring future negotiations on the issue of Cyprus. If Turkey eventually joins, migration restrictions may be imposed. The EU also began accession talks with Croatia in April 2005 contingent on Croatia cooperating fully with the UN war crimes tribunal for former Yugoslavia.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Turkey's EU membership move is crucial for world peace and security, which Tony Blair emphasized as a "fundamental" issue. The deal to open formal talks with Ankara came despite EU demands for Turkey to recognize Cyprus' status and was not guaranteed full EU membership until several years later. Erdogan had to accept negotiations did not guarantee his country's full EU membership and Turkey may have to accept restrictions on migration.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Turkey's deal brings closer EU membership and claims of Muslim-Christian clashes are wrong, indicating Britain's support despite controversy. This move provides an "invaluable bridge" between Europe and the rest of the world while raising concerns about Turkey's integration into the European Union. Turkey's future in the EU remains uncertain due to political issues such as recognising Cyprus, with a 15-year wait before full membership potentially requiring restrictions on migration.
qwen2.5:3b:
Turkey deal 'to help world peace'
A key agreement advancing Turkey's path to EU membership is seen as "fundamental" for global peace and security by Tony Blair. The deal addressed claims of a clash between Muslims and Christians, marking an "historic British objective." Tory leader Michael Howard highlighted this as laying rest fears about the EU being "anti-Islamic." Despite opposition from Turkish leadership over recognizing Cyprus' EU membership status, Turkey's involvement would provide a bridge for Europe to the world. Blair advocated for Turkish membership, citing progress in human rights improvements. EU accession talks with Turkey could extend until 2015 and involve potential migration restrictions. Meanwhile, Croatia’s access is contingent on cooperation with UN war crimes tribunal.
opencoder:1.5b:
A deal bringing Turkey closer to EU membership is of fundamental importance to the peace and security of the world. The European Union has agreed to support the move despite concerns that it could create a clash between Muslims and Christians, which has sparked resistance among countries in Eastern Europe like Germany and Poland.
Turkey's involvement with the EU provides an valuable bridge between Europe and the rest of the world. Mr Howard added that the Tories argued that the EU constitution was not designed to take in a country as large as Turkey.
While Mr Blair has been a leading advocate of Turkish membership despite concerns surrounding the idea, he insisted on making great advances in improving its human rights records. The deal to open formal talks with Ankara came despite an EU demand for Turkey to recognise Cyprus.
Educational discussions have shown that the issue can be tackled at a later date but Turkey’s European President, Şule Aydoğan Erdogan, had to accept negotiations without guaranteeing full membership. An international recognition of southern part of Cyprus is an EU member, while Turkey has previously insisted it would not bow to EU demands for recognition.
If Turkey joins the EU, it may have to accept restrictions to limit migration by its citizens and it will need time to adapt to the changing norms in the European Union.
The EU also announced plans for a start to accession talks with Croatia in April 2005. However, talks between the EU and other countries are likely to be limited due to issues of international cooperation and conflict resolution among European and non-EU members.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise and objective, capturing the main points of the original text while omitting unnecessary details. The key ideas preserved are:

1. Turkey's involvement in the EU: The deal brings Turkey closer to EU membership.
2. Importance of the deal: It is a "fundamental" step towards peace and security for the world.
3. Turkish role: The deal represents an "achievement" of a historic British objective, which was not mentioned explicitly in the original text.
4. Tory leader's statement: Tony Blair said that the deal brought Turkey a step closer to EU membership.
5. Turkish leadership's response: Mr Howard agreed that the EU constitution is not designed to take in a country as large as Turkey and that negotiations can be tackled at a later date, but Turkey's refusal to recognize Cyprus means it cannot join immediately.
6. Tensions over Cyprus: The deal did not guarantee full membership for Turkey, which had previously insisted on recognizing the country.
7. EU's response: The EU will start accession talks with Croatia in April 2005, but talks will begin only if the country co-operates fully with the UN war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Turkey's deal with the EU and its impact on world peace. Let me read through it carefully.

First, it says that a deal is bringing Turkey closer to EU membership, which is important for world peace because of the "fundamental importance" Tony Blair mentioned. Then Tony Blair said that this deal also helped prevent a clash between Muslims and Christians as people pointed out, calling it "wrong." He added that this was a historic British objective.

Next, Michael Howard, the Tory leader, argued that the deal settled any doubt about the EU being anti-Islamic. He suggested that the EU constitution wasn't set up to take a country as big as Turkey, which was controversial because Turkey has its own leadership and hasn't been seen as fully involved with the EU yet.

Turkey's involvement in the EU could be an important bridge between Europe and the rest of the world since it's so large. But Howard said the EU doesn't design for such major countries, which might make some people uncomfortable or suspicious. Tony Blair, despite being a strong advocate, had controversy around Turkey joining the EU.

The deal to open talks with Ankara came because the EU wanted Turkey to recognize Cyprus, an EU member. However, Turkey's position on recognizing Cyprus was strict; it didn't want to join the EU just yet, calling it a red line. It would take up to 15 years to get into membership, and even then, Turkey might have to restrict migration by its citizens.

The EU is also starting talks with Croatia in April 2005, but these talks can only begin if both Croatia and the former Yugoslavia cooperate fully with the UN war crimes tribunal. The deal's importance is discussed among Blair, Howard, and other experts, showing that Turkey's role could have a significant impact on the world's peace.

I think I need to make sure all key points are covered concisely without adding extra details. So, summarizing each main point: turkey closer to eu membership (importance for world peace), deal preventing muhurabah between mukabs and Christians, EU constitution not designed for such large countries, Turkey's role as a bridge, EU's demand for Cyprus recognition, time frame for Turkey joining, and the EU's progress with Croatia.

I should structure this into a few clear paragraphs or sentences without any extra fluff. Let me check if I missed any important details that were highlighted in the original text.
</think>

A deal has brought Turkey closer to EU membership, crucial for world peace due to its "fundamental importance" from Tony Blair. The deal also avoided claims of muhurabah between Muslims and Christians. It represents a historic British objective. Michael Howard argued the EU constitution wasn't designed for large countries like Turkey. Turkey's role as an EU bridge is significant, but debates suggest the EU's constitution isn't tailored for such nations.

The deal opened formal talks with Ankara, partly addressing the EU's demand to recognize Cyprus. Turkey initially refused recognition, marking it a "red line." Membership would take up to 15 years, and Turkey might restrict migration by its citizens. The EU is also advancing with Croatia in April 2005, requiring cooperation from both Croatia and former Yugoslavia under the UN war crimes tribunal. The deal's impact on world peace is discussed among Blair, Howard, and others.
tinyllama:1.1b: The European Council last week reached a deal that could help bring Turkey closer to EU membership. The historic British objective, according to Tony Blair, has been achieved with the provision of "fundamental importance" in relation to the peace and security of the world. The EU constitution is not designed to take in an as-large-as-Turkey country, but Turkish PM Erdogan has accepted negotiations aimed at improving his country's human rights record. The issue on Cyprus can be tackled at a later date but Turkey cannot join the EU until it meets certain conditions, including recognising the southern Cypriot part and accepting restrictions to limit migration by its citizens. If Turkey joins, it may have to accept restrictions to limit migration by its citizens, but discussions will begin only if it co-operates fully with the UN war crimes tribunal for former Yugoslavia.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Turkish deal to join EU membership aims to improve peace and security globally, according to Tony Blair, former UK Prime Minister. The deal brings Turkey closer to EU membership, ending longstanding concerns about the impact of Muslims and Christians in Europe. It also addresses claims of a conflict between Muslims and Christians, with Mr. Blair stating that these were "wrong." The deal to join the EU is important to the peace and security of the world, said Tony Blair, as it represents an "invaluable bridge" between Europe and the rest of the world. Britain's Tory leader Michael Howard has expressed his approval for Turkey joining the EU, citing that it would provide a valuable human rights initiative. Mr. Howard argued that the EU constitution was not intended to include countries as large as Turkey, but the deal reached last week ensures this can be addressed in future negotiations. The international demand for Turkish membership has raised concerns about Cyprus' status within the EU. According to Turkish premier Recep Erdogan, the issue could be resolved later or not at all. Meanwhile, Turkish President Ahmet Tayyip Erdoğan is known for his pro-EU stance, as seen in Turkey's acceptance of the southern part of Cyprus without having to recognize it as a member of the EU.
phi:2.7b: A deal was made at the European Council last week to bring Turkey a step closer to EU membership and is of "fundamental importance" to world peace according to Tony Blair. The deal also dispelled claims that the EU was "anti-Islamic". It's believed that Turkey's involvement with the EU will provide an "invaluable bridge" between Europe and the rest of the world, although Michael Howard argues that the EU constitution is not designed to take in a country as large as Turkey. Despite controversy, Tony Blair has been a leading advocate for Turkish membership in the EU. The issue of Cyprus' sovereignty was resolved with Turkey agreeing to start talks with Ankara, but it will take up to 15 years for Turkey to become an EU member and full accession cannot be guaranteed without accepting certain restrictions on migration. Talks will also begin with Croatia once it fully cooperates with the UN war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
orca-mini:3b: The deal to bring Turkey closer to EU membership is important for world peace and security as it would provide a valuable bridge between Europe and the rest of the world. However, the EU constitution is not designed to take in a country as large as Turkey, and Turkish premier Recep Erdogan had to accept that negotiations do not guarantee full EU membership. The issue of Cyprus recognition can be tackled at a later date, but it may take up to 15 years before Turkey is able to join, and entry cannot be guaranteed. If Turkey joins, it may have to accept restrictions to limit migration by its citizens. However, talks will only begin if the country co-operates fully with the UN war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
hermes3:3b: Turkey, world peace deal closer to EU membership. Tony Blair calls it of fundamental importance for global peace and security.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Tony Blair said that a deal helping Turkey join the European Union (EU) is very important for world peace and security. This deal shows that disagreements between Muslims and Christians are not true. Turkey's involvement in the EU will help connect Europe and other countries. Michael Howard, a Tory leader, thinks this deal proves that the EU isn't anti-Islamic. However, there might be some problems because the EU constitution doesn't include countries as big as Turkey. It could take 15 years for Turkey to join the EU, but they may have to accept some rules about migration. The EU will also start talking with Croatia in 2005.
chatgpt-4o-latest: A deal bringing Turkey closer to EU membership is crucial for global peace and security, according to Tony Blair. He argued it disproves claims of a Muslim-Christian clash and fulfills a historic British objective. Tory leader Michael Howard supported Turkey's role as a bridge between Europe and the world but questioned whether the EU constitution could accommodate such a large country. Despite concerns, Blair highlighted Turkey's human rights progress. The deal allows formal talks despite Turkey's refusal to recognize Cyprus, though this issue will be addressed later. Turkish PM Recep Erdogan accepted that negotiations do not guarantee full membership, which could take up to 15 years and may include migration restrictions. The EU also plans to start accession talks with Croatia in April 2005, contingent on its cooperation with the UN war crimes tribunal.
stablelm2:1.6b: UK leaders say a deal to bring Turkey closer to the EU is essential for global peace and is supported by historic British objectives. The agreement, reached at the European Council last week, contradicts claims of religious conflict and establishes an "invaluable bridge" between Europe and the rest of the world. However, Turkey's involvement requires recognition of the internationally-recognized southern part of Cyprus before it can join, with full membership uncertain due to restrictions on migration. EU has also started accession talks with Croatia after they fully cooperate with the UN war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Turkey's deal to join the EU is deemed crucial for global peace by Tony Blair and an achievement of British importance, contradicting claims of religious conflict between Muslims and Christians. The agreement, reached at the European Council, addresses Turkish human rights improvements and offers a pivotal bridge between Europe and the world, according to Michael Howard, Tory leader. Despite criticism about Turkey's large size for EU membership, the deal allows formal talks to commence, with Cyprus recognition deferred until later. The process could take up to 15 years, and full membership is not guaranteed due to potential migration restrictions. Meanwhile, accession talks with Croatia are set to begin in April 2005, contingent on Croatian cooperation with the UN war crimes tribunal for former Yugoslavia.
reference: A deal bringing Turkey a step closer to EU membership is of "fundamental importance" to the peace and security of the world, Tony Blair has said.The deal to open formal talks with Ankara came despite an EU demand for Turkey to recognise Cyprus.But the Tory leader argued that the EU constitution was not designed to take in a country as large as Turkey.Tory leader Michael Howard said the deal laid to rest any suggestion the EU was "anti-Islamic".The internationally recognised southern part of Cyprus is an EU member, but Turkey, which occupies northern Cyprus, had previously insisted it would not bow to demands to recognise the country, calling the issue a "red line".It was agreed the issue can be tackled at a later date but Turkish premier Recep Erdogan had to accept negotiations did not guarantee his country full EU membership.
